body:
[![Docs](https://img.shields.io/badge/docs-available-brightgreen.svg)](https://r00ster91.github.io/lime/)

# lime

A library for drawing graphics on the console screen

## Features

* Drawing of
  * PNG images
  * text
  * rectangles
  * filled rectangles
  * circles
  * lines
* Non-blocking key input
* Management of the
  * window
  * cursor
  * mouse pointer

## Installation

Add this to your application's `shard.yml`:

```yaml
dependencies:
  lime:
    github: r00ster91/lime
```

Then run `shards install`.

## Example

Three lights flashing repeatedly in order:

```crystal
require "lime"

# Make drawables like Rectangle, Circle available
require "lime/drawables"
include Lime::Drawables

# Create the lights:
# they are red, green and blue rectangles with doubled lines
light1 = Rectangle.new(
  x: 2, y: 1,
  width: 5, height: 3,
  type: Double, color: :red
)
light2 = Rectangle.new(8, 1, 5, 3, Double, :green)
light3 = Rectangle.new(14, 1, 5, 3, Double, :blue)

# The light that is currently on
active = 1

loop do
  if active == 3
    active = 1
  else
    active += 1
  end

  case active
  when 1
    light1.color = :light_red
    light2.color = :green
    light3.color = :blue
  when 2
    light1.color = :red
    light2.color = :light_green
    light3.color = :blue
  when 3
    light1.color = :red
    light2.color = :green
    light3.color = :light_blue
  end

  # Insert the lights into the buffer:
  light1.draw
  light2.draw
  light3.draw

  # Draw the content of the buffer to the screen:
  Lime.draw
  # Clear the buffer so we have room for new stuff:
  Lime.clear

  # You can use `Lime.loop` instead of a normal loop to skip the above two steps

  sleep 0.5
end
```

In the top left corner we can see:

![lights](https://i.imgur.com/hDHDiJB.gif)

See [`examples/`](https://github.com/r00ster91/lime/tree/master/examples) for more examples.

## Contributing

1. Fork it (<https://github.com/r00ster91/lime/fork>)
2. Create your feature branch (`git checkout -b my-new-feature`)
3. Make your changes
4. Format the code (`crystal tool format`)
5. Make sure the specs compile (`crystal spec -v`)
6. Commit your changes (`git commit -am 'Add some feature'`)
7. Push to the branch (`git push origin my-new-feature`)
8. Create a new Pull Request

## Contributors

- [r00ster91](https://github.com/r00ster91) - creator and maintainer

constants.name: Default
constants.doc: Alias for the default rectangle type: `Lime::Drawables::Rectangle::Type::Default`.

constants.name: Double
constants.doc: Alias for the double rectangle type: `Lime::Drawables::Rectangle::Type::Double`.

constants.name: Round
constants.doc: Alias for the round rectangle type: `Lime::Drawables::Rectangle::Type::Round`.

types.name: Lime
types.doc:
The main module of lime.

All x, y arguments are zero-based.

Sometimes you may come across the terms "cell" and "pixel":
* A "cell" refers to one place of a character on the console: `█`.
* A "pixel" **does not** refer to a pixel of a display.
  It refers to the **half** of a "cell": `▀`, `▄` (also called a "half block").

instance_methods.name: buffer
instance_methods.doc: Returns the buffer as a string.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the buffer as a string.

def.name: buffer
def.body:
String.build do |io|
  @@buffer.each do |char|
    io << char
  end
end

instance_methods.name: clear
instance_methods.doc: Clears the buffer.
instance_methods.summary: Clears the buffer.

instance_methods.name: draw
instance_methods.doc: Draws the content of the buffer to the screen.
instance_methods.summary: Draws the content of the buffer to the screen.

instance_methods.name: get_key
instance_methods.doc:
Waits until a key has been pressed and returns it compactly as a symbol.

* `:up` if up arrow has been pressed.
* `:down` if down arrow has been pressed.
* `:left` if left arrow has been pressed.
* `:right` if right arrow has been pressed.
* `:enter` if enter has been pressed.
* `:tab` if tab has been pressed.
* `:backspace` if backspace has been pressed.
* `:escape` if escape has been pressed.
* `:ctrl_c` if Ctrl+C has been pressed.

If none of the above keys are pressed, the key is returned as-is.

NOTE: Ctrl+C is caught by this method and will not be handled by the system.
instance_methods.summary: Waits until a key has been pressed and returns it compactly as a symbol.

def.name: get_key
def.body:
case key = get_key_raw
when "\e[A"
  :up
when "\e[B"
  :down
when "\e[C"
  :right
when "\e[D"
  :left
when "\r", "\n"
  :enter
when "\t"
  :tab
when "\u007F", "\b"
  :backspace
when "\e"
  :escape
when "\u0003"
  :ctrl_c
else
  key
end

instance_methods.name: get_key_raw
instance_methods.doc:
Waits until a key has been pressed and returns it.

NOTE: Ctrl+C is caught by this method and will not be handled by the system.
instance_methods.summary: Waits until a key has been pressed and returns it.

def.name: get_key_raw
def.body:
STDIN.raw do |io|
  buffer = Bytes.new(3)
  String.new(buffer[0, io.read(buffer)])
end

instance_methods.name: line
instance_methods.doc:
Inserts a line from *x1*, *y1* to *x2*, *y2* with *color* into the buffer.

This method uses [Bresenham's line algorithm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bresenham%27s_line_algorithm).
instance_methods.summary: Inserts a line from x1, y1 to x2, y2 with color into the buffer.
instance_methods.args_string: (x1 : Int32, y1 : Int32, x2 : Int32, y2 : Int32, color : Colorize::Color = Colorize::ColorANSI::Default)

def.name: line
def.body:
if (y2 - y1).abs < (x2 - x1).abs
  if x2 > x2
    Lime.line_low(x2, y2, x1, y1, color)
  else
    Lime.line_low(x1, y1, x2, y2, color)
  end
else
  if y1 > y2
    Lime.line_high(x2, y2, x1, y1, color)
  else
    Lime.line_high(x1, y1, x2, y2, color)
  end
end

instance_methods.name: loop
instance_methods.doc:
Like a game loop.
The order is as follows:

**1.** Executes the given block.

**2.** Draws the content of the buffer to the screen.

**3.** Clears the buffer.
instance_methods.summary: Like a game loop.

instance_methods.name: peek_key
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the key that is down in the moment this method is called compactly as a symbol or `nil` if no key is down.

* `:up` if up arrow is down.
* `:down` if down arrow is down.
* `:left` if left arrow is down.
* `:right` if right arrow is down.
* `:enter` if enter is down.
* `:tab` if tab is down.
* `:backspace` if backspace is down.
* `:escape` if escape is down.
* `:ctrl_c` if Ctrl+C is down.

If none of the above keys are down, the key is returned as-is.

NOTE: If the key combination that is down is Ctrl+C, it's caught by this method and will not be handled by the system.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the key that is down in the moment this method is called compactly as a symbol or nil if no key is down.

def.name: peek_key
def.body:
case key = peek_key_raw
when "\e[A"
  :up
when "\e[B"
  :down
when "\e[C"
  :right
when "\e[D"
  :left
when "\r", "\n"
  :enter
when "\t"
  :tab
when "\u007F", "\b"
  :backspace
when "\e"
  :escape
when "\u0003"
  :ctrl_c
else
  key
end

instance_methods.name: peek_key_raw
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the key that is down in the moment this method is called or `nil` if no key is down.

NOTE: If the key combination that is down is Ctrl+C, it's caught by this method and will not be handled by the system.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the key that is down in the moment this method is called or nil if no key is down.

def.name: peek_key_raw
def.body:
begin
  STDIN.read_timeout = 0.01
  get_key_raw
rescue IO::Timeout
ensure
  STDIN.read_timeout = nil
end

instance_methods.name: pixel
instance_methods.doc: Inserts a pixel at *x*, *y* with *color* into the buffer.
instance_methods.summary: Inserts a pixel at x, y with color into the buffer.
instance_methods.args_string: (x : Int32, y : Int32, color : Colorize::Color = Colorize::ColorANSI::Default)

def.name: pixel
def.body:
position = x + ((y / 2) * Window.width_cells)
if color == Colorize::ColorANSI::Default
  default_pixel(position, y)
  return
end
@@buffer[position] = (if y.even?
  if @@buffer[position].to_s.includes?('▄')
    if char = @@buffer[position].as?(Colorize::Object(Char))
      char.back(color)
    else
      (@@buffer[position].as(Char)).colorize.back(color)
    end
  else
    if char = @@buffer[position].as?(Colorize::Object(Char))
      ('▀'.colorize(color)).back(char.back)
    else
      '▀'.colorize(color)
    end
  end
else
  if @@buffer[position].to_s.includes?('▀')
    if char = @@buffer[position].as?(Colorize::Object(Char))
      char.back(color)
    else
      (@@buffer[position].as(Char)).colorize.back(color)
    end
  else
    if char = @@buffer[position].as?(Colorize::Object(Char))
      ('▄'.colorize(color)).back(char.back)
    else
      '▄'.colorize(color)
    end
  end
end)

instance_methods.name: print
instance_methods.doc: Inserts *char* into the buffer at *x*, *y*.
instance_methods.summary: Inserts char into the buffer at x, y.
instance_methods.args_string: (char : Char | Colorize::Object(Char), x : Int32, y : Int32)

instance_methods.name: print
instance_methods.doc: Inserts *string* into the buffer at *x*, *y*.
instance_methods.summary: Inserts string into the buffer at x, y.

def.name: print
def.body:
string.each_char_with_index do |char, i|
  print(char, x + i, y)
end

instance_methods.name: print
instance_methods.doc: Inserts *string* into the buffer at *x*, *y*.
instance_methods.summary: Inserts string into the buffer at x, y.

def.name: print
def.body:
fore = string.fore
back = string.back
string = string.to_s
if (fore == Colorize::ColorANSI::Default) && (back == Colorize::ColorANSI::Default)
  Lime.print(string, x, y)
else
  string = string[((string.index('m')).not_nil! + 1)..((string.rindex('\e')).not_nil! - 1)]
  string.each_char_with_index do |char, i|
    @@buffer[(x + i) + (y * Window.width_cells)] = (char.colorize.fore(fore)).back(back)
  end
end

instance_methods.name: printf
instance_methods.doc:
Inserts *string* formatted into the buffer at *x*, *y*.

This method properly aligns each line in the string beneath each other:
```
Lime.printf("hello\nworld", 2, 2)
```

```text


  hello
  world
```
instance_methods.summary: Inserts string formatted into the buffer at x, y.

def.name: printf
def.body:
i = 0
string.each_line do |line|
  Lime.print(line, x, y + i)
  i = i + 1
end

instance_methods.name: printf
instance_methods.doc:
Inserts *string* formatted into the buffer at *x*, *y*.

This method properly aligns each line in the string beneath each other:
```
Lime.printf("hello\nworld", 2, 2)
```

```text


  hello
  world
```
instance_methods.summary: Inserts string formatted into the buffer at x, y.

def.name: printf
def.body:
fore = string.fore
back = string.back
string = string.to_s
if (fore == Colorize::ColorANSI::Default) && (back == Colorize::ColorANSI::Default)
  Lime.printf(string, x, y)
else
  string = string[((string.index('m')).not_nil! + 1)..((string.rindex('\e')).not_nil! - 1)]
  i = 0
  string.each_line do |line|
    Lime.print((line.colorize.fore(fore)).back(back), x, y + i)
    i = i + 1
  end
end

instance_methods.doc: Returns the buffer as an array of characters.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the buffer as an array of characters.

types.name: Drawables
types.doc:
This module contains drawables that can be inserted into the buffer.

If you want to use the drawables in the Top Level Namespace,
you can `include` them:
```
require "lime/drawables"
include Lime::Drawables
```
types.summary: This module contains drawables that can be inserted into the buffer.

constructors.name: new
constructors.args_string: (x : Int32, y : Int32, radius : Int32, color : Colorize::Color = Colorize::ColorANSI::Default)

def.name: new
def.body:
_ = allocate
_.initialize(x, y, radius, color)
if _.responds_to?(:finalize)
  ::GC.add_finalizer(_)
end
_

instance_methods.name: draw
instance_methods.doc:
Inserts the circle into the buffer.

This method uses the [midpoint circle algorithm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Midpoint_circle_algorithm).
instance_methods.summary: Inserts the circle into the buffer.

def.name: draw
def.body:
x1 = @internal_radius
y1 = 0
err = -@internal_radius
while x1 >= y1
  Lime.pixel(@internal_x + x1, @internal_y + y1, @color)
  Lime.pixel(@internal_x + y1, @internal_y + x1, @color)
  Lime.pixel(@internal_x - y1, @internal_y + x1, @color)
  Lime.pixel(@internal_x - x1, @internal_y + y1, @color)
  Lime.pixel(@internal_x - x1, @internal_y - y1, @color)
  Lime.pixel(@internal_x - y1, @internal_y - x1, @color)
  Lime.pixel(@internal_x + y1, @internal_y - x1, @color)
  Lime.pixel(@internal_x + x1, @internal_y - y1, @color)
  if err <= 0
    y1 = y1 + 1
    err = err + (y1 * 2)
  end
  if err > 0
    x1 = x1 - 1
    err = err - (x1 * 2)
  end
end

constructors.name: new
constructors.doc:
Initializes a new `FilledRectangle`.

*material* is what the filled rectangle will be built with:
```
FilledRectangle.new(0, 0, 5, 5, "#").draw
```

````text
#####
#####
#####
#####
#####
```
constructors.args_string: (x : Int32, y : Int32, width : Int32, height : Int32, material : String = "█", color : Colorize::Color = Colorize::ColorANSI::Default)

def.name: new
def.body:
_ = allocate
_.initialize(x, y, width, height, material, color)
if _.responds_to?(:finalize)
  ::GC.add_finalizer(_)
end
_

instance_methods.name: draw
instance_methods.doc: Inserts the filled rectangle into the buffer.
instance_methods.summary: Inserts the filled rectangle into the buffer.

constructors.name: new
constructors.doc:
Initializes new `Pixels` from an image.

*path* must lead to an PNG encoded image.

constructors.name: new
constructors.doc:
Initializes new `Pixels` from a string.

Iterates through every character of *color_characters* and every time a color character
is found, it's replaced with its color.

Available color characters are:
* `'1'`: default
* `'0'`: black
* `'9'`: dark gray
* `'6'`: light gray
* `'w'`: white
* `'r'`: red
* `'g'`: green
* `'b'`: blue
* `'y'`: yellow
* `'m'`: magenta
* `'c'`: cyan
* `'R'`: light red
* `'G'`: light green
* `'B'`: light blue
* `'Y'`: light yellow
* `'M'`: light magenta
* `'C'`: light cyan

Comments are also allowed in the string.

Example string:

```
# A flower:
 RRR
RYYYR # Head
 RRR
  g
G g G
GGgGG # Stem
 GgG
  g
```

becomes:

![flower](https://i.imgur.com/XaxqEjB.png)

Raises `Error` when an invalid color character is found in *color_characters*.

instance_methods.name: draw
instance_methods.doc: Inserts the pixels into the buffer.
instance_methods.summary: Inserts the pixels into the buffer.

def.name: draw
def.body:
x, y = 0, 0
@pixels.each do |pixel|
  case pixel
  when :newline
    y = y + 1
    x = 0
  when :skip
    x = x + 1
  else
    Lime.pixel(@x + x, @y + y, pixel.as(Colorize::ColorRGB | Colorize::ColorANSI))
    x = x + 1
  end
end

instance_methods.name: map
instance_methods.doc:
Invokes the given block for each of the pixels, replacing the pixel with the pixel returned by the block.
The block must return a `Tuple(UInt8, UInt8, UInt8)`.
```
# Invert colors of an image:
image.map { |pixel| {255u8 - pixel.red, 255u8 - pixel.green, 255u8 - pixel.blue} }
```
instance_methods.summary: Invokes the given block for each of the pixels, replacing the pixel with the pixel returned by the block.

def.name: map
def.body:
@pixels.map! do |pixel|
  if pixel.is_a?(Colorize::ColorRGB)
    Colorize::ColorRGB.new(*yield pixel)
  else
    pixel
  end
end

types.name: Error
types.doc: Raised when an invalid color character is found in a pixel string.
types.summary: Raised when an invalid color character is found in a pixel string.

constructors.name: new
constructors.doc:
Initializes a new `Rectangle`.

For specifying the type, you can use the Top Level Namespace constants
**Default**, **Double** and **Round**.
constructors.args_string: (x : Int32, y : Int32, width : Int32, height : Int32, type : Type = Default, color : Colorize::Color = Colorize::ColorANSI::Default)

def.name: new
def.body:
_ = allocate
_.initialize(x, y, width, height, type, color)
if _.responds_to?(:finalize)
  ::GC.add_finalizer(_)
end
_

instance_methods.name: draw
instance_methods.doc: Inserts the rectangle into the buffer.
instance_methods.summary: Inserts the rectangle into the buffer.

def.name: draw
def.body:
Lime.print(@top, @x, @y)
i = 0
@height.times do
  i = i + 1
  Lime.print(@tile, @x, @y + i)
end
Lime.print(@bottom, @x, @y + i)

constants.name: Default
constants.doc:
The default rectangle type. It looks like this:
```text
┌────┐
│    │
└────┘
```

constants.name: Double
constants.doc:
Like the default type but with doubled lines:
```text
╔════╗
║    ║
╚════╝
```
constants.summary: Like the default type but with doubled lines: `text ╔════╗ ║ ║ ╚════╝ `

constants.name: Round
constants.doc:
Like the default type but with round corners:
```text
╭────╮
│    │
╰────╯
```
constants.summary: Like the default type but with round corners: `text ╭────╮ │ │ ╰────╯ `

class_methods.name: extended
class_methods.doc: Returns `true` if the mouse event report range is extended, otherwise `false`.
class_methods.summary: Returns true if the mouse event report range is extended, otherwise false.

class_methods.name: mode
class_methods.doc: Returns the current mouse event report mode.
class_methods.summary: Returns the current mouse event report mode.

instance_methods.name: extend
instance_methods.doc:
Extends the mouse event report range if *bool* is `true`, otherwise resets the range.

The default X10 mouse protocol doesn't support mouse event reporting with
x, y coordinates greater than 94.
This extends the range to be greater than 94 by using the 1006 SGR (Select Graphic Rendition) mouse protocol.
instance_methods.summary: Extends the mouse event report range if bool is true, otherwise resets the range.

def.name: extend
def.body:
if bool
  print("\e[?1006h")
  @@extended = true
else
  print("\e[?1006l")
  @@extended = false
end

instance_methods.name: get
instance_methods.doc:
Waits for input and returns `Event` if the input is a mouse event,
`nil` if the input is not a mouse event or if `mode` is `Mode::Off`.
instance_methods.summary: Waits for input and returns Event if the input is a mouse event, nil if the input is not a mouse event or if .mode is Mode::Off.

def.name: get
def.body:
if mode.off?
  return nil
end
if @@extended
  return get_1006
end
input = STDIN.raw do |io|
  string = String.new(io.peek)
  io.skip(string.size)
  string
end
if input.starts_with?('\e')
else
  return nil
end
type = case input[3]
when ' '
  :left
when '!'
  :wheel
when '"'
  :right
when '@'
  :left_drag
when 'A'
  :wheel_drag
when 'B'
  :right_drag
when '#'
  :release
when '`'
  :wheel_up
when 'a'
  :wheel_down
else
  :move
end
Event.new(input[4].ord - 33, input[5].ord - 33, type)

instance_methods.name: mode=
instance_methods.doc: Sets the mouse event report mode to *mode*.
instance_methods.summary: Sets the mouse event report mode to mode.

def.name: mode=
def.body:
@@mode = mode
case mode
when .click?
  print("\e[?1000h")
when .drag?
  print("\e[?1002h")
when .all?
  print("\e[?1003h")
when .off?
  off
end

instance_methods.name: peek
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the mouse event happening in the moment this method is called as `Event`,
`nil` if the input is not a mouse event or if `mode` is `Mode::Off`.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the mouse event happening in the moment this method is called as Event, nil if the input is not a mouse event or if .mode is Mode::Off.

def.name: peek
def.body:
begin
  STDIN.read_timeout = 0.01
  get
rescue IO::Timeout
ensure
  STDIN.read_timeout = nil
end

instance_methods.name: kind
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the kind of mouse event based on `type`.

* `:release` if a mouse button has been released.
* `:move` if the mouse has been moved.

* `:click` if a mouse button has been pressed.
* `:wheel` if the wheel has been scrolled.
* `:drag` if a mouse button has been pressed and the mouse has been moved.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the kind of mouse event based on #type.

def.name: kind
def.body:
case type
when :left, :wheel, :right
  :click
when :left_drag, :wheel_drag, :right_drag
  :drag
when :wheel_up, :wheel_down
  :wheel
when :release
  :release
else
  :move
end

instance_methods.name: type
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the type of mouse event.

* `:release` if a mouse button has been released.
* `:move` if the mouse has been moved.

* `:left` if the left mouse button has been pressed.
* `:wheel` if the mouse wheel button has been pressed.
* `:right` if the right mouse button has been pressed.

* `:wheel_up` if the mouse wheel has been scrolled up.
* `:wheel_down` if the mouse wheel has been scrolled down.

Only if `Mouse.mode` is `Mode::Drag` or `Mode::All`:

* `:left_drag` if the left mouse button has been pressed and the mouse has been moved.
* `:wheel_drag` if the mouse wheel button has been pressed and the mouse has been moved.
* `:right_drag` if the right mouse button has been pressed and the mouse has been moved.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the type of mouse event.

types.name: Mode

constants.name: All
constants.doc: Reports all mouse events: movements, clicks and drags.
constants.summary: Reports all mouse events: movements, clicks and drags.

types.doc:
The mouse event report mode.

The default mode is `Off`.

class_methods.name: height
class_methods.doc: Returns the height of the window in cells.
class_methods.summary: Returns the height of the window in cells.

class_methods.name: height_pixels
class_methods.doc: Returns the height of the window in pixels.
class_methods.summary: Returns the height of the window in pixels.

class_methods.name: width
class_methods.doc: Returns the width of the window in cells.
class_methods.summary: Returns the width of the window in cells.

class_methods.name: width_pixels
class_methods.doc: Returns the width of the window in pixels.
class_methods.summary: Returns the width of the window in pixels.

instance_methods.name: scrollbar=
instance_methods.doc: Disables or enables the alternative buffer which doesn't has a scrollbar.
instance_methods.summary: Disables or enables the alternative buffer which doesn't has a scrollbar.

instance_methods.name: title=
instance_methods.doc: Sets the title of the window to *title*.
instance_methods.summary: Sets the title of the window to title.

instance_methods.name: update
instance_methods.doc:
Updates the values of `width`, `height` and
`width_pixels`, `height_pixels`.
instance_methods.summary: Updates the values of .width, .height and .width_pixels, .height_pixels.
